reviewText: Every once in a while TV shows us just how good it can be.  This series was one of those times.  Shame on the studio that produced this wonderful show for not releasing these episodes in a complete series boxed set with director and cast commentaries and interviews.  The entire cast was great, but it was Regina Taylor that I fell in love with.  She endowed Lily with great personal strength and dignity.

reviewText: A great and incredible series on the historical significance of racism and fight for equal rights. A series that also shows the importance family and the time for the young growing up in the 1950s. A series that can be watched again and again.

reviewText: You would think with Chase's success with the Sopranos and the full set of Northern Exposure DVD's that they would finally release I'll Fly Away in a complete set.  It ran for the better part of two seasons before being yanked, only to offer a sense of closure in a final episode the following year.  Brand and Falsey deserve the lion's share of credit for this excellent series that brought the civil rights era to life for another generation to see, but David Chase had a directoral hand in at least two episodes.The parallels between Sam Waterston's D.A. Forrest Bedford and Gregory Peck's Atticus Finch are obvious, but the heart and soul of the show was Regina Baker as Lily Harper.  The casting was superb from the wonderful kids that Lily found herself raising, in addition to her own wonderful daughter, to Kathryn Harrold as Christina.Like all of Brand and Falsey's television series, I'll Fly Away captured a time and place and made it come alive.  They dealt with so many thorny issues but never came across as pedantic, with a strong focus on family and how Forrest's role as a DA affected them,  You got a very good impression of what it was like to grow up in the rural South during the late 50s.  Telling the story through Lily was a masterstroke, erasing the paternalistic attitude so many shows dealing with that era take and giving you a deeper insight into the black community when the episodes focused on her personal family, including her father, played with understated elegance by Bill Cobbs.I hope we will see it very soon on DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Going through the VHS collection and came across my vcr-recorded copies of I'll Fly Away(PBS airing) a few weeks ago. We finished watchin' the last episode, Then & Now, tonight. Wow! By far, one of THE best series ever produced and shown on TV. All the tapes played well, luckily. Most of the episodes were taped in EP mode. Video shows very well and the audio sounds fine...for videotape that's a couple decades old. Missing one episode, though, according to the episode listing. This series has always been one of our favorites. We wished they would make available a complete DVD boxed set w/the Behind-The-Scenes mini-documentaries that were shown along with the PBS airings. Regina Taylor(Lilly) and Sam Waterston(Forrest) gave brilliant performances. Jeremy/Jason London(Nathan), Ashlee Levitch(Francie) and John Aaron Bennett(John Morgan) acted as brothers and sister would. And Lilly's father and daughter, Bill Cobbs(Lewis) and Rae'ven Kelly(Adlaine) were outstanding. Brad Sullivan's performance as the Warriors wresting coach is pure genius. All gave their best and it shows in each episode. It was nice spending the last few weeks with the Harpers and the Bedfords.I'll Fly Away tells many stories. The Civil Rights Movement is the key story, though. And this series shows it. It doesn't hold back any punches. A rare gem.Please release the I'll Fly Away TV series on DVD. Soon.Thanks.

reviewText: This was one of the most beautifully acted series ever, please, please someone put it on dvd so we can all see it again, it would be worth watching over and over.  It was thought provoking, heartfelt, very real and was almost exactly how our family lived at that time.
summary: I'LL Fly Away with Sam Waterson and Regina Taylor, tv series
Title: N/A

reviewText: With the recent release of the feature film "The Help", I am hoping for a dvd release of this "classic" American tv series, which has, at its core, one woman's quiet determination to break through the unjust barriers existing at the turbulent time of America's Civil Rights movement. Regina Taylor's portrayal of central character "Lily Harper" is nothing short of exquisite.  Of course, it must be a classic American tv series, as it was created by Joshua Brand and John Falsey of "St. Elsewhere" fame.  It is essential that "I'll Fly Away" be released on dvd sometime soon.

reviewText: I found this series one of the best series on TV.  The actors did an incredible job giving their characters heart and making us see the difficulties faced by those living in the South at that time.  You are not only entertained, but you learn a bit about the history of our country.

reviewText: "To Kill a Mockingbird" is my favorite book and movie. There hasn't been a film that has moved me so much. When "I'll Fly Away" premiered on TV, I watched and was fascinated. It was one of the best human dramas I'd ever seen. Updated to the 60's, there is no element of "Mockingbird" that isn't prevalent...the racism, the lawyer, the kids and the love...and the hate. The human condition is well examined. Sam Waterston and Regina King both won awards for their powerhouse performances in the short-lived series. The TV audiences just weren't there, and, despite great reviews and lots of awards, the series, pitiably, was cancelled. Those moments of charm, heart, conflict, renewal, intelligence, and resolve are too precious to ignore. Please! Where's the DVD !
summary: Brilliant TV version of "To Kill a Mockingbird"
